stem: The nurse is navigating complex clinical decisions. Match each ethical principle with its correct description.

columns.text: Supporting the client's right to make their own healthcare decisions.
Acting in the best interest of the client to provide positive benefit.
The duty to 'do no harm' and protect the client from injury.
The fair and equitable distribution of resources to all clients.
The duty to be truthful and honest with the client.

rationale.correct: Ethical principles guide nursing practice in difficult situations. (r1) Autonomy = Self-rule. (r2) Beneficence = Doing good. (r3) Non-maleficence = Avoiding bad. (r4) Justice = Fair share for all. (r5) Veracity = Truth-telling.
rationale.incorrect: Fidelity (not shown) refers to the nurse's commitment to fulfill promises and maintain professional boundaries.
clinicalPearls: An example of Justice in 2026 is ensuring that health technology and AI benefits are available to rural and low-income populations as much as urban ones.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: Beneficence is 'Proactive' (Doing good). Non-maleficence is 'Protective' (Preventing bad).

mnemonic.title: A-B-N-J-V
mnemonic.expansion: Autonomy (Alone), Beneficence (Better), Non-maleficence (Never harm), Justice (Just/Fair), Veracity (Verify/Truth).

reviewUnits.heading: Applied Ethics for Nursing
reviewUnits.body: Nurses use ethical frameworks to solve dilemmas. The Code of Ethics for Nurses provides the foundation for these decisions.
reviewUnits.source: ANA: Code of Ethics for Nurses with Interpretive Statements
